pros: Everyone is so friendly and committed to College Track’s mission. I trust my coworkers and we treat each other fairly and with dignity. It’s the most positive work experience I’ve had so far. Great benefits too, we get 401 match, health, vision, dental, flex accounts, two weeks Christmas vacation and one week summer vacation as well as two weeks accruing vacation, so starting off you get 5 weeks per year! They try to match pay with fair market rates.
cons: It is a nonprofit so upward mobility might be difficult, especially for part timers.

pros: Directors are adequately compensated. Travel premium offered.
cons: Site director through me under the bus for his own mistakes and fired me, convincing his boss of his narrative. Nothing was done at the top to prevent him from exerting his power until the other employees did a work strike a year later and he was fired.

review_title: Mission Driven - Challenges with Transparency/Decision Making
job_title: College Success Advisor in Oakland, CA
pros: * People - Staff were some of the dopest and down people to work with. Generally positive and a desire to support student excel in high school, through college and onward to upward mobility. Students were also generally lovely to support. * Mission driven org - you feel like you're doing good work * Culture building (sometimes cheesy) but a high value on authenticity * Funds designated for students experiencing emergencies - * Funds students could access in college that they earned in high school through GPA score, GPA improvement, attendace, and volunteer hours in their communities
cons: * Challenges in communicating decision making processes and practices to staff. I remember asking the new CEO Dr. Collado about how she plans to address on longitudinal effect of staff feeling unsure or lacking trust in relation to how decisions are both made and communicated. She said that in her conversations while onboarding to the role - the "length of time " decisions took to make was the challenge vs the equity in decision making. Essentially saying that her anecdotal data was more accurate over 4 years of quantitative data *At will employment status (techincally you could be let go for any reason or no reason at all) Can feel scary if you provide critical feedback. * CT has been in transtion mode for the past 3 year. It was hard to acclimate to the job when systems within the org changed from year to year - I can't imagine how hard it must be now.

pros: Community and mission - strong commitment to the work
cons: Ambiguity and inconsistent cultural leadership

pros: loved working here before the shift in national leadership
cons: not truly focused on students needs

pros: Students, extended staff, summer closure

review_title: The best organization I've worked for
pros: The company culture is grounded in the students, but not at the expense of the staff. The compensation structure is transparent and they pay in the middle of their competitors. The hybrid schedule allows me to get some in-person time, while also having the flexibility to work from home sometimes.
cons: As an organization that has experienced significant growth recently, College Track is still finding the right balance with regards to inclusivity and speed with regards to its decision-making processes and structures.

pros:
Great mission
Committed and motivated staff
Management has well defined and articulated strategic plan
cons:
Lack of flexibility in work location
Some managers are not as strong as others

pros: You can tell that College Track cares a great deal about the students and employees. They offer many paid trainings that teach you to become a better educator. In addition, they offer many resources for students whether they are a top student or a student who is struggling in a class. I believe anyone would benefit from working with College Track.
cons: Some days were more hectic, while others were very slow.

pros: I love the culture there
cons: None I can think of

review_title: Outdated approach + Dysfunctional climate + Significant turnover = Poor leadership
pros:
Admirable mission
Tons of financial resources at its disposal
Good track record of college matriculation (although, know for “creaming” it’s student population)
Forward thinking founders
cons: 12 locations - 5 site director vacancies, 5 new site directors (<1.5 years with the organization) and 2 veteran site directors with more than 2 years in the organization. Turnover rate is similar for all director level positions across the organization. 23 year history, though operates like a start-up. Turnover has not been a product of reorganization, just poor leadership at every level of the organization.

job_title: Program Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: The students are great and the program's mission is good.
cons: TFA program alum were given preference in all positions simply because the CEO is an alum himself.  Poor overall management.  Site staff were treated like peasants during fundraising events.  Salaries are not very good considering that you have to work until 8 or 9pm on weekdays, and a lot of Saturdays.

pros: A very well organized and funded non profit that does an awesome job at valuing cohesion between departments and making it's employees feel heard and appreciated. This organization loves it's employees as much as the community of students is seeks to empower.
cons: benefits are lacking especially for part time employees

job_title: Academic Advisor in New Orleans, LA
pros: One of the best reasons is because of the hourly wage of $13.50/hr if you want to be an academic advisor.
cons: Most of the students won't cooperate and listen to you if you ask if they need help. I wouldn't recommend applying to this job in New Orleans.
